The project will improve the quality and reliability of electricity supply, reduce the aggregate technical and commercial (ATC)
losses in electricity distribution, and restore the financial sustainability of the rural electricity supply. These will be achieved by (i)

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Uttar  Pradesh  Power  Distribution  Network 
Rehabilitation  Project.  The  report  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA) for  Enhancing 
Community  Participation,  Gender  Mainstreaming,  and  Institutional  Capacity  Building  of  Uttar 
Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL); and if the Board approves the proposed MFF, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA.1 
 
2. 
The  project  will  improve  the  quality  and  reliability  of  electricity  supply,  reduce  the 
aggregate  technical  and  commercial  (ATC)  losses  in  electricity  distribution,  and  restore  the 
financial sustainability of the rural electricity supply. These will be achieved by converting low-
voltage  distribution  lines  to  aerial  bundle  conductors  (ABCs),  separating  the  11-kilovolt  (kV) 
feeders supplying agriculture consumers from those supplying rural households to facilitate the 
rationing  of  electricity  supply  to  agriculture  consumers,  improving the  financial  management  of 
UPPCL, and deepening community engagement to improve electricity supply cost recovery and 
gender inclusivity in rural electricity distribution–related activities. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE 

 
Access to electricity. Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state with close to 220 million 
3. 
people, has a poverty rate (29%), higher than the national average (21%) and suffers from lack 
of economic opportunities. In FY2018, its per capita electricity consumption of about 400 kilowatt-
hours (kWh) was lower than the national per capita consumption of 960 kWh.2 UPPCL added 8 
million rural connections and 1 million urban consumers from 2017 to 2019, raising the rural and 
urban consumer base to 17 million and 9 million, respectively under the SAUBHAGYA scheme 
supported  by  government  of  India. 3 With  the  completion  of  this  scheme,  Uttar  Pradesh  has 
substantially advanced the “energy for all” objective with a household electrification rate of over 
80% in 2020 compared to around 55% in 2016.   
  
4. 
Affordability of electricity and cost recovery. The Uttar Pradesh government has the 
policy of subsidizing the electricity supply to its poor consumers, and maintained the lifeline tariff 
(for consumption below 100 kWh/month) for residential consumers at ₹3.35/kWh compared with 
the  supply cost  of  ₹7.85/kWh.  Based  on the  socio-economic  survey  undertaken  during  project 
preparation, this rate is considered affordable for the poor with estimated expenditure outlay of 
$200/month/household to meet 60 kWh/month electricity requirement of a typical poor household. 
In  addition,  the  electricity  tariffs  for  residential  consumers  consuming  above  the  lifeline 
consumption  and  agriculture  consumers  for  water  pumping  are  also  maintained  below  cost 
recovery level. UPPCL, a state-owned enterprise responsible for bulk power purchase and power 
distribution in Uttar Pradesh, required about ₹60 billion fiscal transfer to cover its cost of electricity 
supply in FY2018.  
 
5. 
 Furthermore, UPPCL has low collection efficiency, collecting only 77% of billed revenue 
in FY2019. Collection efficiency in rural areas is below 50%, mainly due to rural households’ poor 
payment discipline. Agriculture consumers are supplied by unmetered connections and billed a 
fixed monthly charge based on normative electricity consumption linked to the contracted water

Technical issues of electricity distribution. The rural electricity supply in Uttar Pradesh 
is  characterized  by  (i)  frequent  power  interruptions  and  (ii)  an  overloaded  and  dilapidated 
electricity  distribution  network.  From  2011  to  2019,  the  Government  of  India’s  Deen  Dayal

grants and loans to UPPCL to improve the rural medium-voltage distribution network (33 kV and 
11  kV),  including  separating  the  11  kV  feeders  supplying  residential  consumers  from  those 
supplying agriculture consumers in selected areas. Although these investments have improved 
the medium-voltage network, the rural distribution network still requires investment of about ₹60 
billion. 
 
7. 
The  investments  under  the  DDUGJY  as  well  as  SAUBHAGYA  schemes  have  led  to 
improved average supply duration in rural Uttar Pradesh from 12–13 hours/day before 2017 to 
16–18 hours/day in 2019. However, rural electricity supply is still saddled with low performance 
of  distribution  infrastructure,  overuse  of  electricity  by  agriculture  consumers,  low  collection 
efficiency, and poor service to customers. ATC losses stood at 36.8% across Uttar Pradesh in 
FY2019.  The  poor  quality  of  electricity  supply  is  one  of  the  contributory  factors  to  low  socio-
economic  development  in  Uttar  Pradesh  compared  to  more  progressive  states  in  India.  The 
proposed project is designed to resolve long-standing technical and financial management issues 
that  continue  to  significantly  hamper  electricity  sector  performance.  The  project  is  the  first 
investment in Uttar Pradesh’s electricity sector financed by an external development partner since 
2001. 
 
8. 
Coronavirus  disease  impacts.  As  a  result  of  the  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19) 
pandemic,  India’s  economy  is  projected  to  contract  by  9%  in  the  fiscal  year  2020/21,  before 
rebounding sharply with  8.0% growth in FY2021/22, assuming the pandemic wanes in  2021.5 
With  revenue  falling  sharply  and  expenditure  rising  to  fight  the  pandemic  and  support  the 
economy, the fiscal deficit at both central and state level is expected to rise  sharply in FY 2020/21. 
The  government  of  India  has  arranged  a  liquidity  injection  facility  to  overcome  the  short-term 
cashflow  constraints  of  distribution  companies  such  as  UPPCL  due  to  COVID-19-related 
economic downturn, and to enable the timely payment to generation companies by distribution 
companies.  The  proposed  project  will  complement  post-COVID-19  recovery  efforts  by  the 
government  by  providing  (i)  short-term  benefits  through  construction-related  jobs  including  to 
migrant workers who were displaced by containment measures; (ii) medium-term improvement to 
UPPCL’s performance, reducing the need for fiscal subsidies; and (iii) long-term benefits through 
improved electricity supply, attracting investments to industry and commerce. The fiscal space 
created  by  reduced  fiscal  subsidy  requirement  to  the  power  sector  will  enable  the  state 
government to allocate additional resources to poverty reduction and social safety nets. 
 
9.

agreed on a sector road map under the Ujwal DISCOM Assurance Yojana (UDAY) scheme for 
UPPCL’s financial turnaround through debt restructuring and operational efficiency improvement 
in 2016.6 The UDAY road map consists of (i) a financial restructuring plan to improve UPPCL’s 
debt sustainability, and (ii) an operational improvement plan. The UDAY road map sets out key

Policy framework. The policy and regulatory framework governing the electricity sector 
14. 
in  India  and  Uttar  Pradesh  aims  to  promote  least-cost  electricity  supply  and  full  cost  recovery 
through appropriate electricity tariffs, coupled with revenue subsidies from the state government. 
The Uttar Pradesh Electricity Regulatory Commission (UPERC) regulates the electricity sector in 
Uttar Pradesh. UPERC determines the tariffs for different consumer categories to recover ACS 
after allowing for certain level of cross subsidies from industrial and commercial consumers to 
agriculture and residential consumers. The Uttar Pradesh government has decided to keep the 
tariff below the cost recovery level for residential consumers using less than 100 kWh/month and 
for  agriculture  consumers.  It  has  been  compensating  UPPCL  through  statutory  transfers  as 
required under the Electricity Act, 2003 to supply electricity to poor households and agriculture 
with a tariff below the ACS. 
 
UPERC determines the aggregate revenue requirement of UPPCL to provide adequate 
15. 
cashflows to meet the eligible expenses based on certain normative efficiency standards and earn 
a regulated rate of return on the equity capital. However, because of operational inefficiencies 
and  the  prevalence  of  unmetered  connections,  UPPCL  does  not  operate  at  the  normative 
efficiency  standards  set  by  UPERC  for  ATC  losses.  The  regulatory  framework  is  designed  to 
encourage  UPPCL  to  operate  at  the  normative  efficiency  standards  stipulated  by  UPERC, 
however UPPCL’s underperformance in reducing ATC losses and improving collection efficiency 
is resulting in financial losses. The proposed investments under the project will provide substantial 
assistance  to  UPPCL  to  improve  its  operational  performance  and  meet  UPERC’s  normative 
efficiency  standards.  This  will  enable  UPPCL  to  eliminate  the  gap  between  ACS  and  ARR  and 
reduce its financial losses.

35. 
ADB staff members undertook technical due diligence of the project to establish the need 
to rehabilitate the distribution network by (i) converting the low-voltage network to ABCs, and (ii) 
separating the 11 kV feeders supplying residential consumers from those supplying agriculture 
consumers. Electricity  distribution companies in several Indian states have converted their low-
voltage networks to ABCs and successfully reduced technical and commercial losses in electricity 
distribution. Feeder separation enables the DISCOM to control the duration of electricity supply 
to agriculture consumers to limit overconsumption by unmetered agriculture consumers. 
 
B. 
 
Economic analysis.  ADB staff members conducted the economic analysis of the project 
36. 
following  ADB  guidelines.  The  analysis  evaluated  the  economic  costs  and  benefits  in  FY2019 
constant  prices  for  FY2020–FY2050.  The  economic  benefits  mainly  come  from  behavioral 
changes  to  conserve  electricity  induced  by  project  interventions  as  described  in  the  economic 
analysis.24 The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing the with- and 
without-project  scenarios.  The  project  is  economically  viable  with  an  EIRR  of  14.5%,  and  the 
project’s  expected  net  present  value is  ₹22.6  billion  at  an  economic  discount rate  of  9.0% per 
year. The sensitivity of the EIRR was assessed for the following adverse scenarios: (i) insignificant 
consumer behavior changes, (ii) reduction in the generation cost, and (iii) reduction in willingness 
to pay for electricity. The project’s economic viability is robust under these adverse scenarios. 
 
37. 
Financial  analysis.  The  financial  analysis  of  the  project  followed  ADB’s  guidelines  for 
financial  management  and  analysis  of  projects. 25 The  analysis  did  not  quantify  COVID-19’s 
financial  and  economic  impacts  as  these  are  expected  to  last  12–18  months  and  will  not 
significantly  affect  the  project  over  its  lifetime.  However,  sensitivity  analysis  has  been  run  on 
possible project implementation delays because of COVID-19. The project’s estimated financial 
internal rate of return in real terms is 10.38% compared with the project’s weighted average cost 
of capital in real terms of 4.0%. ADB staff members performed an analysis to assess the sensitivity 
of the financial internal rate of return to adverse changes in key variables, including (i) less-than-
expected decrease in distribution losses, (ii) increase in operation and maintenance costs, and 
(iii)  delay  in  project  completion.  The  results  of  the  sensitivity  analysis  confirmed  the  project’s 
financial viability under these adverse scenarios.
